page.title: 18CHEESDEN VALLEY IND. (2)
page.content:
The spinning and weaving machines for both wool and cotton were powered by water wheels. The soft stream water from the gritstone moors was ideal for various finishing processes. For example Cheesden Lumb Mill (built in 1786) was a fulling mill where the woollen cloth from the nearby cottage weavers was processed and given a 'felted' texture.
The coming of the industrial revolution and the advent of steam power led to the demise of the textile industry in this area. Very few of the mills transferred to steam power.
